maml:description.maml:para: Connect to an OPNsense server using the REST api
The Connect-OPNsense cmdlet will try to connect to an OPNsense server REST api. You need to specify the Key and Secret obtained when enabling the REST api.
The Url must include the base Uri of the OPNsense api, which is usualy /api. Also specify the appropriate protocol (http:// or https://) in the Url.
If the server is using a self-signed certificate and your computer fails to validate it, you can temporarily disable the Certificate Validation using the -AcceptCertificate switch.
Full URI of the OPNsense REST api including the protocol, hostname and ending in /api.
The REST api key generated by OPNsense.
The REST api secret generated by OPNsense.
Bypass the server certificate validation, use this for accepting self-signed server certificates.
Full URI of the OPNsense REST api including the protocol, hostname and ending in /api.
The REST api key generated by OPNsense.
The REST api secret generated by OPNsense.
Bypass the server certificate validation, use this for accepting self-signed server certificates.
Disable a CronJob in OPNsense
Disable a CronJob in OPNsense using its UUID. The UUID can be retrieved with Get-OPNsenseCronJob.
UUID of the CronJob to disable
UUID of the CronJob to disable
Disconnect from an OPNsense server REST api
The Disconnect-OPNsense cmdlet will remove any reference to the connected OPNsense server. You will have to use the Connect-OPNsense cmdlet again to reconnect.
Enable a CronJob in OPNsense
Enable a CronJob in OPNsense using its UUID. The UUID can be retrieved with Get-OPNsenseCronJob.
UUID of the CronJob to enable
UUID of the CronJob to enable
Return the basic status information about the OPNsense server

Use this command to list basic status information of the OPNsense server, like its Product Version and Product Name. The command will first contact the mirror repository and check if any updates are available.

Use the Get-OPNsense cmdlet to retrieve the number of updates pending and to check whether a reboot will be needed. If updates are available, use the Update-OPNsense cmdlet to install them and reboot the server when required.
Retrieve one or more CronJobs from OPNsense
If you do not specify an UUID the Get-OPNsenseCronJob cmdlet retrieves a list of all the CronJobs from OPNsense.
By passing a UUID to Get-OPNsenseCronJob the cmdlet will only retrieve the details of the specified CronJob.
UUID of the CronJob to retrieve
UUID of the CronJob to retrieve
Get a list of the packages in OPNsense
Retrieve a list of the packages in OPNsense.
Retrieve information about one or more packages in OPNsense.
Install a Package in OPNsense
Install one of the available OPNsense software packages on the server.
The Name of the package to be Installed
The Name of the package to be Installed
Run pkg audit -F on the server
FreeBSD registers vulnerabilities for its packages and we though that made a nice addition to a security project to create visibility and awareness.
Execute an OPNsense command against the REST api of a connected server
The Invoke-OPNsenseCommand cmdlet will execute a command againt the OPNsense server REST api. This can be a simple query. You can also POST objects using a simple Form or complex Json structure.
Use the Connect-OPNsense cmdlet first to establisch a connection. Subsequent calls will not need credentials until you disconnect using Disconnect-OPNsense cmdlet.
If you specify an AddProperty HashTable, the Objects returned will each include the properties specified.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Post JSON object --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-OPNsenseCommand ids settings test -Json @{ key1 = value1; key2 = value2 }

maml:description.maml:para: Lock a Package in OPNsense

The Lock-OPNsensePackage cmdlet locks the version of a package. It prevents the package from being updated by subsequent OPNsense updates. Use the to prevent unintended upgrades or downgrade to the package.
The name of the package to be locked
The name of the package to be locked
Remove a Package in OPNsense
Uninstalls a Package from the OPNsense server.
The name of the package to be removed
The name of the package to be removed
Reboot the OPNsense server
The Restart-OPNsense cmdlet will reboot the OPNsense server. Use this command with care, as this will make your appliance inaccessible while it restarts.

In order to prevent accidental reboots, the command will request user confirmation before executing the command on the OPNsense server. You must specify the -Confirm parameter if you want to reboot the server without user intervention.
Ask user confirmation before restarting the OPN server.
Ask user confirmation before restarting the OPN server.
Shutdown the OPNsense server

The Stop-OPNsense cmdlet will shutdown the OPNsense server. Use this command with extreme care, as this will make your appliance inaccessible. Make sure you have a means to power the server on before executing this cmdlet!

In order to prevent accidental shutdown, the command will request user confirmation before executing the command on the OPNsense server. You must specify the -Confirm parameter if you want to power down the server without user intervention.
Ask user confirmation before powering down the OPN server.
Ask user confirmation before powering down the OPN server.
Unlock a Package in OPNsense

The Unlock-OPNsensePackage cmdlet unlocks the version of a package. It allows the package to be updated by subsequent OPNsense updates. Use the to allow updating the package to the latest version using the Update-OPNsense cmdlet.
The name of the package to be unlocked
The name of the package to be unlocked
Update the OPNsense server base OS and packages

The Update-OPNsense cmdlet will run the update tool and install the pending updates on the OPSsense server. Use the Get-OPNsense cmdlet to retrieve the number of updates pending and to check whether a reboot will be required.

Because the server will reboot automatically when required, user confirmation is requested before updating the OPNsense server. You must specify the -Confirm parameter if you want to reboot the server without user intervention.
Ask user confirmation before updating the OPN server.
Ask user confirmation before updating the OPN server.
Retrieve system health data from OPNsense

Use the Get-OPNsenseSystemHealth cmdlet to retrieve statistics about the OPNsense system health. There first switch determines the type of data returned and can either be [ -Packets | -System | -Traffic ] For Packet and Traffic statistics you need to specify the interface for which to return the data. For System statistics you need to specify the resource for which to return the data.

Use the Get-OPNsenseInterface cmdlet to retrieve a list of the available interfaces you can query. Use the Get-OPNsenseSystemResource cmdlet to retrieve a list of the available resources you can query.
The other parameters are optial and common to all commands. They specify the start and end date and resolution and zoomlevel of the data.
You can also use Inverse to make outgoing interface values negative. By default all data is shown as positive numbers.
Return packet statistics
The inferface for which to return packet or trafic information
Not implemented
Not implemented
Display outgoing values as negative
Return traffic statistics
